com.irurueta.server.commons.email

Class HtmlEmailMessage<E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.irurueta.server.commons.email.EmailMessage<E>
      • com.irurueta.server.commons.email.HtmlEmailMessage<E>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - internal type to be used by email sender implementation.
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ApacheMailHtmlEmailMessage, JavaMailHtmlEmailMessage

    public abstract class HtmlEmailMessage<E>
extends EmailMessage<E>
    Abstract class to build emails having HTML markup as in webpages. These kind of emails are useful for marketing purposes or simply to get a nicer layout. Files can be attached as in text emails, or they can be sent inline so they can be used within the html content (such as images or css resources to be used within html email body).

    • Field Summary

    • Field Detail

      • mHtmlContent

        private String mHtmlContent
        HTML content of email to be rendered as a web page.

      • mAlternativeText

        private String mAlternativeText
        Alternative text to be shown on clients not supporting HTML content.

      • mEmailAttachments

        private List<EmailAttachment> mEmailAttachments
        List of attachments to be included in email. Attachments are shown in mail clients as files that can be downloaded from the email.

      • mInlineAttachments

        private List<InlineAttachment> mInlineAttachments
        List of files to be embedded inline within the email so they are shown as part of the html content. These files can be used within the HTML body as images, css resources, etc. In order to use this resources within the HTML markup, and id must be provided on each inline attachment and the same id must be used within the HTML markup. If no id is generated, one will be randomly created, and placeholders of the form {0}, {1}, etc will be filled within the HTML markup in the same order as the inline attachments are provided.

    • Method Detail

      • getHtmlContent

        public String getHtmlContent()
        Returns HTML content to be rendered in this email as a webpage. HTML content can have placeholders in the form {0}, {1}, {2}, etc where id's of resources can be automatically embedded inline for those attachments where no id is provided. Notice that HTML content can also use regular external links, but some email clients might block those links for security reasons.
        Returns:
        HTML content to be rendered as a webpage.

      • setHtmlContent

        public void setHtmlContent(String htmlContent)
        Sets HTML content to be rendered in this email as a webpage. HTML content can have placeholders in the form {0}, {1}, {2}, etc where id's of resources can be automatically embedded inline for those attachments where no id is provided. Notice that HTML content can also use regular external links, but some email clients might block those links for security reasons.
        Parameters:
        htmlContent - html content of email to be sent.

      • getAlternativeText

        public String getAlternativeText()

        alternative text.

      • getEmailAttachments

        Returns:
        list of files to be attached.

      • setEmailAttachments

        public void setEmailAttachments(List<EmailAttachment> emailAttachments)
        Sets list of files to be attached. Attachments are shown in mail clients as files that can be downloaded from the email.
        Parameters:
        emailAttachments - list of files to be attached.

      • getInlineAttachments

        public List<InlineAttachment> getInlineAttachments()
        Returns list of files to be embedded inline within the email so they are shown as part of the html content. These files can be used within the HTML body as images, css resources, etc. In order to use this resources within the HTML markup, and id must be provided on each inline attachment and the same id must be used within the HTML markup. If no id is generated, one will be randomly created, and placeholders of the form {0}, {1}, etc will be filled within the HTML markup in the same order as the inline attachments are provided. For instance an image in the HTML can be defined either as <img src="cid:some-id"/>, or instead a placeholder can be used such as <img src="cid:{0}"/>.
        Returns:
        list of files to be embedded inline.

      • setInlineAttachments

        public void setInlineAttachments(List<InlineAttachment> inlineAttachments)
        Sets list of files to be embedded inline within the email so they are shown as part of the html content. These files can be used within the HTML body as images, css resources, etc. In order to use this resources within the HTML markup, and id must be provided on each inline attachment and the same id must be used within the HTML markup. If no id is generated, one will be randomly created, and placeholders of the form {0}, {1}, etc will be filled within the HTML markup in the same order as the inline attachments are provided. For instance an image in the HTML can be defined either as <img src="cid:some-id"/>, or instead a placeholder can be used such as <img src="cid:{0}"/>.
        Parameters:
        inlineAttachments - list of files to be embedded inline.
